Tonight we remember what Jesus did for us on the cross. I am planning on doing a traditional service with worship and reading of the seven words spoken by Jesus on the cross. After each word is spoken we will extinguish one of seven lights until there is only one light left. With the last light we will all quietly leave the church and close the doors and await the joyous news of Jesus' resurrection on Sunday morning. Those of you from a liturgical or "high" church background will recognize footwashing and Tennebrea. Those of you from a more free and casual church background will wonder what we are up to with these "rituals". When rituals occur year after year without explanation they can become old and stale and meaningless. But when they are used afresh they can be very powerful ways of communicating essential truths. In our context of Japan, there is always something lost in the translation. So acting out God's truth is a powerful way for people to know Him.

Tonight we will have a footwashing service here at Grace. I simply love the awesome symbolism of this act, that the Lord of all creation would stoop down to wash His disciples feet. Jesus then said to His disciples that if He washed their feet then they ought to wash one another's feet. What does it mean? It means that if you can't forgive people then you can't serve them. There will always be a reason not to serve. They "need" to learn to do it for themselves, they should respect their elders, they haven't served like they should, it is not your ministry, it is not your job -- the excuses go on and on. But Jesus didn't give any excuses, He simply gave us His example. Let's follow His example.

I am really enjoying this little book by Joseph L. Cannon a missionary in Japan about a generation ago. It is called "For Missionaries Only" and is full of wonderful nuggets. Here is an excerpt entitled Jack of All Trades, Master of None What is a missionary? What is he supposed to do? I have never met a missionary that wasn't an astute juggler of many balls, a switch hitter who played all the positions, a chameleon called upon to reflect every situation, a variety store, a mulligan stew, a strange mixture of heaven and earth. think of what a missionary is called upon to do, and what he does. he is a financier, a public relations man, a fund raiser. He must be an educator, a personnel director, an able administrator. he must be a linguist, a translator, interpreter, author, and publisher. He must be a practicing physician, nurse and first aid man, a counselor, anthropologist, and sociologist. he is expected to be an English language expert, an ambassador of his country, to have a keen insight inot national and international politics, and alwasy be able to take the right position on any problem that arises. He is a philanthropist, organizer and operator of benevolent institutions, a lecturer, orator, and teacher of many things. We might add that he preaches the gospel once in a while, too! We have a saying, "Circumstances alter cases," and this aptly applies to the role of the missionary. The missionary's own background, education and inclination effect his role. What a missionary does and can do is determined, also, by how old he is, how long he has been on the field, the education level of a people, the climate of the country, the economic level of its society and the political stability of an area. All are factors that influence the work of a missionary. A changing world can mean a changing role for the missionary. But there is one trade the missionary must be master of to deserve the name. I want to emphasize that the missionary is primarily a gospel preacher, a bearer of good news. His work is to save souls. There should be only one mission for his life, one role that must supersede all others, in order to be worthy of the name "missionary." This is the unchanging role assigned by the Great Commission, "Go ye into all the world and preach the gospel..." In too many cases, the missionary becomes a Martha, troubled and worried about many things. He needs to hear the Lord when He says, "Only one thing is needful," and like Mary, choose the better part. Though he may be busy doing many good things, if he fails to proclaim the gospel, he will see fruit without a tree, light without a sun, water will blow and nothing will remain. His field of many labors will be a valley of dry bones. He will have failed because, among the accumulated wares of a life with many roles, he will have left dust-covered, and neglected, the most important role of all -- his mission to seek and save the lost. Oh Lord, that I would stay focussed on the one mission that supersedes all the rest!

Technology just keeps on racing along at breakneck speeds changing the nature of what we are doing. If you think back 150 years it is incredible how technology has brought the mission field closer. 1. Travel -- physically getting there is easier. 2. Medicine -- staying physically well is easier. 3. English -- English has become the 2nd language of the world, making being understood easier. 4. Communication -- urlLink Video , Radio and the Internet have all made getting the word out easier. Even in the last 15 years there have been significant changes in Japan that my life as a missionary. When I first got here getting foods from my home country was next to impossible for somebody on a missionary budget. On the rare occasion that we would go to a foreign specialty shop downtown and try to purchase something American we would go through sticker shock first. Now there is a Costco only a half hour away! Ditto for other products such as electronics with English language manuals or books and materials in English. These days it is as easy as ordering something online. Communication with home is as simple as starting up my computer. If mom and dad are online I get them on the instant messaging and we can "chat" in real time. The other day we even set up a web-cam and traded pictures back and forth. When I first got here calling home meant that the telephone bill was going to be huge that month. All of this means that it is easier for us missionaries to live here without getting as isolated and homesick as we used to. But at the same time, it is easier to wrap ourselves in a "foreign" cocoon and never really become part of this community that we have come to reach for Christ.

One more, this one entitled What I Like About the Missionary Life Pioneering with the gospel! This is the great thrill of missionary work. Starting from scratch, not building on another's foundation. Bringing souls to Christ who have never heard of Him before. Reaching people with the gospel who never had a chance before. Sharing to a little degree the ambition of the apostle Paul. This is the missionary spirit! This is the spirit of adventuring by faith! What a great adventure it was for Christ to leave heaven and come to earth. What challenges to His soul! What a life of new and unforgettable experiences! How worthwhile it was! What happiness was brought to millions. In missionary life, you go by faith into the unknown. You bet your life on the promises and providence of God. You are willing to take risks for the sake of the gospel. Away with the life of self-centered coddling! Away with the comforts of home! Away with the false security of this world, and forward into the real security of dependence on God. This missionary pushes his frail bark into unknown seas. This fool of Christ risks all, yet gains all. What a joy to this happy pioneer to arrive in strange places, and find Christ is there. To find Christ in the happy eyes of those who obey the preached gospel. To teach songless hearts to sing, and see hopeless hearts begin to hope. To go where there is no church of Christ and see born before your very eyes the kingdom of God. This is what I like about the missionary life. This too is what I like about the missionary life. I went on my first missionary trip with the high school youth group when I was 16. I came back from that trip to Mexico knowing that this was the life for me.

Here is another excerpt from "For Missionaries Only" The expert looked me in the eye and said, "What do you suggest we do to reach the missionary's goal of establishing indigenous churches?" I didn't mean to be rude, but I answered, "That's not this missionaries goal." My friend stiffened a little at this for he was of the persuasion that "the responsibility of the missionary on the field is to build self-governing, self-propagating, and self-supporting native churches." I don't want to be contrary, but I have always thought of my goal and responsibility as a missionary in a different light. With Paul, I feel like my responsibility is "to preach the gospel" and establish Christ-minded, Christ-loving, Christ-supporting Christians. After all you can have self-governing, etc. churches that are selfish, not willing to love and help others. It is possible to have a church of self-propagating devils. You can have self-supporting, sectarian, and anti-every-good-work churches. Here is another bit, In the New Testament the whole church is described as one united body, with every one depending on the other, and local churches depending on each other, as per the text of this section (Eph 4:15-16). Independence can mean isolation, and isolation death. Interdependence can mean "bodily growth... up-building itself in love. There is nothing that I want to see more as a missionary than the church to take off in Japan like a wildfire that spreads into every city and town. For that to happen surely they will have to be Japanese (not missionary) churches. But if I start trying to design for that to happen by putting artificial restrictions on the gospel then I am misguided. If I say that I will only preach to Japanese, or only allow Japanese in my church, or only train up Japanese then I will be missing out on the other people that God wants to bring into His kingdom and wants to use to help bring in the Japanese.

I am working today on an Equippers seminar to train people to study the bible on their own and to teach others. Ephesians tells us that God gives some gifts so that they can equip the saints for the work of the ministry and build up the body of Christ and 2 Timothy tells us that it is the scriptures that are to be used to equip us for every good work. We are going to hold the first seminar this month on the 23rd and 24th. My plan is to teach inductive bible study, actually how I study God's word so that they can dig out teachings of their own that are both scriptural and also fresh and real because they found it for themselves. How I study the bible is first to observe what is really written there. The trick is to get past what I think is written, what somebody else told me was written and what might be hidden by either language or culture that I might have missed. The second part of my study is to interpret what is written. Usually this means that I start asking questions -- how does this square with another passage dealing with the same topic? What does this have to do with Jesus' example in the gospels? What about the Old Testament? I always let the Bible explain the Bible first. Finally, I need to make the jump between knowledge about Scripture to application of it to my life. The question I usually ask here is "So what?" What difference does it make to my life that Paul didn't want Titus to get circumcised? Usually this is the most difficult part of the process and requires the most prayer. I chug through observation and interpretation like a steam train, slowly but surely it will all make sense. But the application part is where I have to listen to God and allow Him to shape my heart and life. It is also the part where all of my study can have the most impact for God's kingdom both in my life and also in the lives of those that I teach.

Another idea that I had yesterday came under the heading of "Riding on Public Transportation". I thought that if I wanted to go to Shinjuku, I would not try to create my own road or my own way of going there but I would ride on the train or go on the road just like everybody else. When the Apostle Paul travelled around the world preaching the gospel he did not create a new way, but followed the roads that the Romans had so ingeniously built. So if I want to reach a certain community with the gospel it would only make sense to use the routes that already exist. If I want to reach university students it makes no sense to create a new organization that then has to find a way in. Instead we need to send Christians into the organizations that already exist -- not to change those organizations but to serve them. But at the same time to serve Christ and lift up his name in that community. We need to ride on public transportation. Do we go to the head office of JR (Japan Railways) and ask permission to use the railways throughout Japan to spread the gospel? No, we pay the fare and hop on just like millions of other people who are using it to get to work, or go to school or wherever. We are just using it to get to our place of ministry. Of course we have to abide by their rules and keep from inconveniencing other passengers but there is no reason why we cannot quietly share Jesus with the person sitting next to us. In the same way we can be Christian members of a million different communities in our towns and cities, paying our fare, pulling our weight and playing by the rules of that community but at the same time sharing Christ by our words, actions and attitudes! I can create a new community which I then try to pull people into, or I can go out into the communities that already exist find hundreds to share Christ with. What communities are you a part of? How can you be a better witness to Christ in that community?

One of my biggest frustrations with doing ministry in Tokyo was that it was so big that I never felt like I was making a difference. It seemed that I could lead someone to Christ on the train, or talk to someone about Jesus in a coffeeshop but then that person would live far away in Chiba or Saitama and we could never follow them up and help them to grow in Christ so that they could be a witness in their circles. Ministry in Ome has been much better in this respect as here we are able to meet people again and again and follow them up. The community is key. Now there are communities like "Yotsuya Mura" all over Tokyo where people do know each other and there is opportunity for deeper ministry it is just that we need to find where those communities are.

I finished reading the biography of Dawson Trotman this morning. I think there were four main values that this man of God inspires me to emulate. 1. Personal Discipline -- Trotman planted the word of God in his heart, constantly memorizing scripture. The results of this planting are evident in the vast impact that the man had on so many Christian leaders of his generation. 2. Follow-Up -- Trotman went for years leading people to Christ only to see so many of them fall away. His breakthrough came when he stressed personal discipleship of each person won for Christ. God opened the door wide for this through the Billy Graham crusades. 3. Working with Others -- Trotman never hesitated to work alongside other groups such as Graham, YFC, Young Life, Wycliffe and others. He wasn't about making a name for himself or the Navigators, but about seeing the kingdom of God grow. 4. Concentrating on a Few -- Trotman experienced working with multitudes and working with a few in a concentrated manner and found that the latter produced more long-lasting fruit.

Each of us needs to have the sword of the Spirit, God's word, constantly at our side so that we don't become vulnerable to the attack of the enemy. Those who are skilled at the use of the sword need to pass along that knowledge so that many can fight, rather than keeping it to themselves so that their position is secure. "And next to them Melatiah the Gibeonite, Jadon the Meronothite, the men of Gibeon and Mizpah, repaired the residence of the governor of the region beyond the River." (Nehemiah 3:7) In the midst of chapter 3 of Nehemiah where everyone is working on repairing the walls and rebuilding the gates, here are a few guys who are working on the house of the Persian regional governor. This would probably just be the house that he would stay in when he was in town, but the fact that it needed repair meant that it had been pretty much ignored until then. Sometimes even when the physical building is in full swing we still need to spend time and resources to build up and restore key relationships as well. Lord, help me not to overlook key relationships. Help us to keep the ones we have fully maintained and give us favor with those over us.

"Then I sent to him, saying, "No such things as you say are being done, but you invent them in your own heart." Nehemiah 6:8 The next trick Nehemiah's enemies thought up was to spread lies about what Nehemiah was trying to do. Especially they wanted to make it appear as if he was disloyal to the King of Persia. Actually this was really a threat to try to make them fearful so that they wouldn't complete the work. When people lie about us it is not up to us to prove that they are lying, it is not up to us to defend ourselves. We can trust that God will strengthen our hands and that He will defend our case. We might think that people are believing their lies and that our situation is worsened, but in the long run all lies are exposed and it is those who spread lies who are the losers.

"But they thought to do me harm." Nehemiah 6:2b By this time the work on the wall was almost complete, so the enemies of Israel turn their attacks toward Nehemiah himself. One way these enemies worked was through distraction. They wanted to meet together with him. Nehemiah said, "Why should the work cease while I leave it and go down to you?" Who should we meet with and why? If we want to "ride public transportation" we need to make relationships with the gatekeepers of these organizations. Nehemiah had a key relationship with the King of Persia and he was rebuilding the house of the Governor beyond the river. So it is important to meet with these people. It is also important to meet with our friends in the work. There was a huge amount of coordination and cooperation that needed to take place and so Nehemiah needed to meet with the leaders of each group. But Nehemiah didn't bother to go meet with his enemies because he knew that if he went "down" to their level he would get stuck in the muck and the work would suffer.

10 Cities Around Ome Our city of Ome is nestled up against the mountains on the far western edge of Tokyo. Over the mountains to the north is Hanno, and over the mountains to the south is Akirunoshi and Hinodemachi. If you go up into the mountains directly to the west there is the small village of Okutamamachi. If you follow the Tama river downstream you come to the cities of Hamura, Fussa and Akishima and if you follow the Ome Kaido (The main highway that leads from Ome down to Shinjuku in the center of Tokyo) you come to the cities of Mizuho and Iruma. 10 Cities around Ome 81,989 Hanno 147,909 Iruma 32,892 Mizuho 56,779 Hamura 62,316 Fussa 78,351 Akirunoshi 16,631 Hinodemachi 7,575 Okutamamachi 106,532 Akishima 141,394 Ome Total Population: 738,300 Altogether with Ome these 10 cities are home to three quarters of a million people. It is not much compared to the 26 million that live in the entire Tokyo metropolitan area, but still a lot. Considering that only about 1% have any faith in Christ at all, there is also a lot of work to do. Each of these cities have existing churches, however there are not enough churches even to care for the 1% that supposedly have faith! The result is that many people who have at one time made a confession of faith, or have been baptized, no longer attend church or fellowship with a body of believers. The reality of this is that these Christians are weak and demoralized and are not living in victory or making a difference for the kingdom of God. Similar conditions exist all over Tokyo and indeed the situation only gets worse as you go farther away from the capital into the countryside of Japan. How can we expect the church to advance for the kingdom of God, when we are not even taking care of those who have already received Christ? Jesus said, "Well done, good servant, because you were faithful in a very little, have authority over ten cities." (Luke 19:17) If we want to see many come to Christ we need to be faithful in the very little that has been entrusted to us.

Every Sunday during the services I give people a chance to share testimony about what God is doing in their lives. The result of these testimonies is that the whole body is encouraged in their faith and they begin to expect that God will work in their lives as well. But of course not everybody gets to share on Sunday. Usually it is only one or two. What would happen if everyone got to share every week, not just about the big things but the little things as well? We would find that the whole body would be expecting God to do wonders! 2. All who believed were together and had all things in common. In the large church context it becomes difficult to love one another in practical ways. Although there are needs and plenty of resources to meet those needs it is hard to connect the two together. Usually any attempt to do so becomes something stiff and institutional. However, in a home fellowship when there is a need it is obvious and those who can meet that need have a heart to do so. Through these small groups loving one another becomes very natural. 3. So continuing daily with one accord in the temple... with gladness and simplicity of heart, praising God and having favor with all the people. One of the biggest turnoffs about the church is when we bicker and argue with each other. The reason why they were in one accord was because their needs were being met as they broke bread from house to house. There was no need for envy or strife between them but just gladness and simplicity of heart. 4. And the Lord added to the church daily those who were being saved. Acts 2:47 "Four Functions of Home Fellowships" "And they continued steadfastly in the apostle's doctrine and fellowship, in the breaking of bread, and in prayers." At last weekend's Equippers Seminar we talked and shared a lot about how these four things happen in the home fellowships and how it is different from what typically takes place in a Sunday worship service. 1. They continued steadfastly in the apostle's doctrine I think what is key here is that we are not just to be hearers of the word but also doers, or as it is phrased here, "continuers". During the sermons on Sunday and Tuesday night Bible studies I teach the word in a rather general fashion. I paint the picture with broad brush strokes and pray that the Holy Spirit will fill in the details as to how the truth applies to each individual life. It is not really possible at that time for someone to interrupt and ask whether they are understanding the Spirit correctly. This is where the home fellowship can be really helpful -- in encouraging one another to apply this general teaching more specifically to life. The idea then is not so much to introduce new content, but to help each other apply and continue on in the teaching that you have already received. 2. They continued steadfastly in fellowship It is quite possible for someone to come to a worship service and never feel as if they are part of the family. Masachika and Yuki shared how at their home fellowship Kaoru prayed for their daughter's upcoming piano recital. These "little" things are some of the most important ways that we can love each other. 3. They continued steadfastly in the breaking of bread Not only with communion but with any meal shared together, there is a real acceptance and unity that takes place. Karla sent me an e-mail from back in the U.S. about how meaningful our weekly curry lunch after the service was to her, because it gave her a chance to get to know people. 4. They continued steadfastly in prayer There are prayer needs (and praise reports) that will never make it to the big stage. They aren't really important enough to ask the whole church to pray or to tell the whole church about. But in the home fellowship setting there is nothing too small to share and to pray about together.

The Amateurisation of Ministry...? I was reading yesterday on a blog about urlLink plasticbag.org | weblog | (Weblogs and) The Mass Amateurisation of (Nearly) Everything... It was talking specifically about weblogs, but more generally about how publishing, journalism and many other things like photo processing and making movies are being taken out of the professionals office or studio and into the home for any Joe with a computer. I am a beneficiary of this for sure. I use iPhoto, iMovie and blogger to roll my own movies and slideshows and keep people informed about what is happening in the ministry here in Japan. The article above reasoned that this is mainly because equipment and information is now readily available where before it wasn't. The cost of entry has come down so low that anyone can get involved. The upshot is that where a missionary/church in the past could not afford to produce a movie documenting their ministry, I am producing movies regularly to do everything from promoting the next retreat to showing people what our church is about. Where it would have been impossible for us to produce (and mail) a magazine even yearly with color photos to all of our supporters, we can now provide them with daily updates at minimal cost. This amateurization not only lowers the cost of creating things, but actually allows a vast larger of things to be created that never would have been created before. Now hold on a moment. Shouldn't some things remain professional? Last week in the prayer update devotional, urlLink "Signal to Noise Ratio" I mentioned that we need to consider the quality of the source when we look at information which is why the Bible tells us to "Set your mind on things above, not on things on the earth." With now millions of people all logging on with their thoughts and ideas about everything, how do you know what is true? How do you know what is quality? This is where we turn to the professionals. If some piece of news shows up on a few blogs it is interesting but if the same things starts showing up on CNN then it has more weight. But this isn't the only meaning of the word "professional." We are used to thinking in terms of a professional being someone who gets paid and exhibits a higher quality of work. But there is a deeper meaning that we should not forget. A profession is not just a career but also a statement of faith or belief. The word "professional" comes from the idea of "professing" something. The original professions were all paths of life that required their practitioners to make a profession or oath. Examples of this would be the medical profession and the legal profession. They are called professions because they swear to uphold an oath. This is different from tradesmen or artisans who are seeking to increase wealth by buying and selling or creating a product. The professions serve a higher purpose that is supposed to be above simply seeking after personal gain. Ministers are also one of the classical professions because they are called into the ministry and serve God rather than man. The question then becomes, do we want to amateurize the professions? Do we want to sell kits to do plastic surgery at home? Should there be one-click litigation available online? Actually, I don't think that is what is going to happen. The mass amateurization we are beginning to see online is one of craft and not of profession. Many of the things that were once done by skilled craftsmen and artisans with expensive tools and equipment are now being accomplished by people like me with little skill and a computer. But the professions require more than just skill and equipment. They require belief in something higher, whether that be health, law, or God. Now one of the main tenents of the Protestant Reformation was the "Priesthood of all Believers", the idea that we do not need a priest to stand between us and God because Jesus has closed the gap. Recently, there has been renewed interest in the church in making less of a distinction between clergy and laity, and many sermons have been preached urging people to get out of the pew and into the world to minister unto the lost. This is right and good as the church had become something of a spectator sport rather than a participatory one. But where should we draw the line between professional and amateur? If everyone is a minister then who should I listen to when my "ministers" all say different things? There are some who would seek to disperse the church, do away with the paid minister, and have the body minister unto itself. They think that this would solve the problems. They are correct in that there is ordained ministry that is amateurish and immature. There is also ministry that is unordained and yet of extremely high quality. But the New Testament example is that while every part of the body has a role to play and is essential for the whole, there is a need for some to be called; to go, to speak out, to proclaim, to pastor and to teach. There is a need for those who will trust God to make them sufficient to the ministry and not seek commendation from men. There is a need for those who will not be swept to and fro by every opinion poll or passing fad, but will seek first the things above. There is a need today for professional ministry. For us to profess our faith in God and serve Him by serving the flock that He has put into our care.

Two weeks ago a group of us guys took a two day hike up Mt. Kumotori (Cloudgrabber!) Here are some pictures. We had a great time but were exhausted by the end of it. We started out at Okutama lake and left my little car down by the end of the trail where we hoped to come out. We didn't really even get onto the trail until around 3 in the afternoon as most of the guys had to work and Jonathan was moving in the morning. So by the time we got on the trail it was already starting to get dark. The first stretch of trail was the steepest, as usual! What made it really rough was that my pack was heavy. I usually go on day hikes so there was quite a bit of difference in the weight. By the end of the trail I was going really slow and it was pitch black -- but we were hiking with headlamps so we were able to see. I was the last of the group to make it to the expected campsite but when I got there it turned out that we were to be charged 400 each and we would not be permitted to build a fire! You have to understand, it was VERY COLD. So for the next half an hour I climbed to the top of the ridge on sheer indignation! The making of fire became quite an ordeal as most of the wood around was very wet and there was a lot of wind as well. By the time someone remembered that we had napkins that we could use to get it started we had spend about an hour messing around with it. But in the end we got hot dogs roasting and with a little food in my stomach I was ready for bed. The next problem was that we had forgotten to bring one of the tents. So we had six guys in one four man tent. This meant that while it was warm enough inside no one was really able to stretch out enough to get the kinks out of their legs. Mark was kind enough to let me use his sleeping pad so I did pretty well. Actually once I got stretched out on it I was hurting so bad that he didn't have the heart to tell me to get off! The next morning we got up bright and early to see Mt. Fuji -- what an awesome view! The stars the night before weren't bad either. We hiked along the ridge to the top of Mt. Kumotori, the highest peak in Tokyo. Mark came up with a great idea, that we could leave all the gear at the tent until we came back down, so I travelled light and did great until we got back. The trail down from our camp was just about vertical and didn't seem to ever end. It was relentless. When we finally hit the road we thought our troubles were over, but in reality they had just begun. The road stretched for another 5 kilos mostly steep downhill before it reached my car. Needless to say we were some very tired hikers by the time we got down. But I did get up and preach three times the next day!

This is a good article in the New York Times about being homeless in Japan. urlLink For Japan's New Homeless, There's Disdain and Danger Japanese society places a high degree of importance on conformity. This conformity is enforced in many ways but one way that has been enforced is through "ijime" or bullying. The weak, oddball is picked on at school and routinely beat up by those who are considered normal. Children are very clear about what is right and wrong and have a strong sense of justice. (They also know how to lie and manipulate as well...) But if children see someone else doing something that their parents told them not to do they see no problem in pointing out their fault or even going so far as to punish them for it. So in a conformist society like Japan, the homeless become targets for youth. I think it is an extension of the whole "ijime" problem. Why is there such a homeless problem in a country as rich as Japan? The same conformity issue is to blame. When workers such as those described in this story come up against problems they don't know how to find a creative solution. Their whole lives they have simply been part of the system. So when the system fails they don't know what to do. Nowadays, with more homeless people being seen, it becomes easier to choose "homelessness" as a legitimate alternative when other options don't work. In other words, like everything else in Japan, if there is a group of homeless people that you can join then it is alright. I think there are quite a few young men who have found an easy way out and should not really be homeless. These men need guidance and opportunity before they get too used to the homeless life.

YEAR IN REVIEW 2003 Praise the Lord! 2003 was a big year for us and for Grace Christian Fellowship. Some of the most significant things are hard to see in the monthly overviews but are real blessings from God. Over the last 2 years over 60 people have received Christ through this ministry, but whereas in 2002 most people prayed with me to receive Christ, in 2003 there were many who came to salvation through others in the body. Pray that more and more people in the church would experience the joy of leading someone to Jesus! Another huge leap forward has been the growing numbers of people who are willing to serve and take leadership of ministries. Most of the events of this last year were not planned or put on by me, none of the home fellowships are led by me, and I am no longer leading worship for any of the three services (except in a pinch). R-Scale: One of the concepts that is thrown around a lot in missions is that of the "unreached". However, it is a difficult thing to define. The point of course is that in strategic thinking we want to know where we should send new missions and where those missions will be most effective. The idea is that cross-cultural missions should be sent to those areas that are as yet unreached, while the indigenous churches of each nation that has been reached can handle the continuing evangelization of that country. This concept of the "unreached" and also "people groups" has led to wide-spread popularization of the "10-40 Window", meaning the portion of the earth's surface that has the most unreached people for Christ. I have a hard time with the term "unreached" because it is very vague. At what point should a nation be considered "reached". Everyone knows that even though the average town in America is very "reached" there is still plenty of evangelism and ministry that needs to happen. So how can we decide that one area is more needy than another? Some rough guidelines have been talked about. One way of doing it is dividing the world up into A, B, and C regions depending on how reached or unreached they are. But this still doesn't answer the question, "How do we decide which of these groups a given region should be in?" If a church has been established is it now reached? What about the health of that church? What about the density of churches to population? What about percentage of Christians to the general population? I think all of these need to be factored in to find if a nation is truly reached or unreached. I have been playing around with some ideas about how to measure the relative effectiveness of the gospel in certain region. The key factors that I think are important for a given locality are, X = number of Christians Y = number of Churches Pop = general population a simple formula that gives us a relative scale of "Reachedness" then would be, (Pop/x * Pop/y) / 1,000,000 = R (higher number means greater unreachedness) For example, my town of Ome, Japan would be a 4.48 on the R-Scale according to this calculation. The higher the number the more needy for the gospel a place would be. One benefit of this kind of calculation is that it allows us to compare geographic areas of different size in a meaningful way. Here is a chart of various locations in Japan on the R-Scale. Tokyo Prefecture pop/y = 12,286 pop/x = 107 R = 1.31 Ome City (In Tokyo) pop/y = 17,500 per 1 church pop/x = 256 per 1 Christian R = 4.48 Hokkaido Prefecture pop/y = 14,000 per 1 church pop/x = 254 per 1 Christian R = 3.5 Toyama Prefecture pop/y = 27,400 pop/x = 686 R = 18.7 Okinawa pop/y = 6,161 pop/x = 94 R = 0.5 Saga Prefecture pop/y = 30,368 pop/x = 550 R = 16.7 Takushi ( a town in Saga Prefecture) pop/y = 24,000 pop/x = 3,000 R = 72 (adding one more church of 12 would drop it down to 14) All this does is give us a meaningful number of relative reachedness for comparing regions beyond just the percentage of population that is Christian or the number of churches in an area. At some point it should be possible for the indigenous church in an area to effectively reach their area (and indeed send missions to other areas) without undue support from the outside. What that number would be is yet to be seen. These numbers might be most useful simply in comparing one area of the same region to another rather than comparing different countries. An R of "1" in one setting might mean a thriving local church that is experiencing revival while an R of "1" in another setting might mean a church in decline that needs to be revived. But this would be a start in making useful comparisons in determining how far we have to go in completing the task that Jesus has set before us.

Near many train stations in Japan there is a back street where you can find a club that advertises "Western Women". Many of these women are from eastern Europe and have been brought in with very different expectations that what they discovered when they arrived. These clubs used to feature mostly Asian women but the landscape is once again changing. This article, urlLink Laws provide little help for sex slaves explains that part of the problem is that laws do not treat these women as victims but as criminals themselves. Keiko Otsu, the director of urlLink HELP women's shelter, said: "The police have begun to make real efforts toward combating this problem. However, there needs to be a system where the victims are protected rather than treated as criminals." In most cases, women who were in such a situation and reported it to the police have been arrested for visa violations, and deported to their country of origin, often at their own expense. There also are no specific laws in Japan that deal with human trafficking and those convicted of human trafficking are usually only fined or given the equivalent of a slap on the wrist under the relevant laws. In response, the U.S. State Department listed Japan as a country that did not sufficiently comply with antitrafficking guidelines in their urlLink Trafficking in Persons Report 2003. The report stated: "The Japanese government does not aggressively prosecute and punish the criminal organizations involved in trafficking. It does not provide adequate protection for victims." Pray for Christians to respond to the plight of these women and to reach out to meet the needs that they have. Pray for the government of Japan to do deal justly and fairly with this issue.

The science section of the New York Times reports, urlLink New Data Shows Mysterious Force in Universe, as Einstein Said In 1917 Einstein predicted that an unseen engergy permeating space is pushing the universe apart. This is a good thing because otherwise the gravitational pull of all those billions of stars and galaxies would cause the universe to collapse in on itself in a "big crunch". Einstein named this force "The cosmological constant" but recent theorists seeking to explain the mysterious force have suggested that it could become stronger or weaker over time -- either tearing the universe apart or allowing it to collapse in on itself. Well, good news! Einstein was right in calling it a "constant" because new data from the Hubble Space Telescope measuring the push of this force on supernovas shows that even over extremely long periods of time there is no variation. Kind of reminds me of James 1:17, "Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and comes down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of turning." Perhaps there is some connection between the mysterious force that holds the nucleus of an atom together and the mysterious force that keeps the universe from crashing in or ripping itself apart. It seems that the Creator loves us in many more ways than we have yet discovered and His love is indeed constant.

This is an op-ed from the NY Times that is more pointed and accurate than most of the media hype about "Passion" urlLink Op-Ed Contributor: Do You Recognize This Jesus? Watching "The Passion of the Christ," Mel Gibson's new movie, I kept thinking the following: it is Christians, not Jews, who should be shocked by this film. Mr. Gibson's raw images invade our religious comfort zone, which has long since been cleansed of the Gospels' harsher edges. Most Americans worship in churches where the bloodied body of Jesus is absent from sanctuary crosses or else styled in ways so abstract that there is no hint of suffering. In sermons, too, the emphasis all too often is on the smoothly therapeutic: what Jesus can do for me. More than 60 years ago, H. Richard Neibuhr summarized the creed of an easygoing American Christianity that has in our time triumphantly come to pass: "A God without wrath brought men without sin into a kingdom without judgment though the ministrations of a Christ without a cross." Despite its muscular excess, Mr. Gibson's symbol-laden film is a welcome repudiation of all that." I haven't seen this movie yet of course. But I am wondering what the reaction of the Japanese will be to this film when it comes to Tokyo in May. I think it will be a good correction to the view that many have of Jesus as a good teacher and of the cross as some kind of good luck charm.

Recent news about the effectiveness of abstinence programs in the US are reporting things in a really one-sided manner. Here is a better angle on the story. urlLink Abstinence Programs Proven Effective, But Not Foolproof Abstinence Programs Proven Effective, But Not Foolproof If you ever want to see an egregious example of press spin, not to mention shallow science reporting, just read the New York Times and glance through the headlines on any given day. The latest example is a headline reading "Study Finds That Teenage Virginity Pledges Are Rarely Kept." Although I have a bone to pick with cultural conservatives, I'll get to them later. Now I'm going to pick on the left-leaning bias of the press, and slipshod reporting when it comes to matters of science. I've scanned several news sources, and all pretty much ape the New York Times' coverage of this story, some nearly word-for-word: 88% of teens who take a pledge not to have premarital sex wind up breaking it, and those kids have almost (almost) as much risk for developing STDs. Therefore, the press suggests, the study "challenges the assumptions underlying the Bush administration's promotion of abstinence programs." Pfaugh! If you ever needed proof that reporters are, for the most part, completely ignorant about science, and tend to be reactionary about conservative ideals, you can look no further. Not only is the negative spin ridiculous, but they don't see fit to name the study or where you can go to read a copy of the original. Most of the press accounts haven't bothered to point out that these abstinence programs were first brought to the national scene by the Clinton administration, either. The Bushies have only continued what the Clintonistas created. But let's look at what the press accounts tell us, when you ignore the spin and look at the (rather measly) data they've actually reported about the study: 1) 12% of the kids keep their pledge and never have sex before marriage. If I told you I could reduce the rate of heart disease or cancer by 10% with a certain program, almost any doctor on the planet would consider that exciting news. Indeed, just this week, physicians everywhere were excited to learn that certain drugs reduce risk of heart disease by 16%, and as high as 26% in some cases. So it seems to me that if we can confidently state that abstinence programs reduce teen sexual activity by more than 10%, they cannot rationally be called a failure. The numbers could be better, but then again, these programs are in their infancy and might well be modified to improve those odds. 2) All the press accounts say that the kids who take the abstinence pledge wind up contracting STDs at almost--almost!--the same rate as kids who don't take it. Implication: there's probably a minor reduction. 3) The press accounts all acknowledge that kids who took the pledge delayed onset of sexual activity by an average of 18 months. This is a huge reduction. 4) Mysteriously, not a single one of the press accounts mentions pregnancy. But why is it that I find it impossible to believe that kids who delay having sex by an average of 18 months, with 12% of them never having sex at all before marriage, are likely to be a group of kids who have a lower overall unwed teen pregnancy rate? Why is this not in the reporting? 5) The press accounts all acknowledge that the kids who took the pledge are more likely to get married. They also say the kids who take the pledge and break it "wind up having sex before marriage," but what percentage of those are kids who have sex with their fiance/fiancee? They don't bother saying.

This just in from Mark Penner and the ViBi (Visual Bible for Japanese Deaf) project. Webcam sessions with our translator in Japan are going well. Long distance communication is sometimes frustrating, not to be able to point to a word in his Hebrew interlinear, draw a map or write out a character, but we're making good progress nontheless. Last night, we finished our first draft through Genesis 15. I work evening/night hours to adjust to Japan time, and try to catch up on sleep in the mornings. One big challenge we face is making or finding Sign Language place names for the many towns, cities, and countries in the Bible. For the genealogical lists and passages like Genesis 10's "List of Nations", we will run the names across the screen in Japanese, but where place names are not part of a list, we need sign names. Names of people are sometimes a problem too. Deaf people make names for each other based on prominent physical characteristics or events in their lives. As long as we know something about the person, we can usually find a way to make a viable sign name, but when we know nothing at all, we have a problem (as in Adah and Zillah in Genesis 4:19-23). Perhaps someone is looking for a way to help our project. If you are willing to look through the whole Bible for non-list people with no information about them in the text, that would help us prepare. If this sounds like something you'd like to try, drop me a line. Thanks. Anybody want to take him up on that?

It took me a while to get to the bottom of this, but it seems that there is something happening in regards to teaching evolution in the classroom. Of course this is a subject that won't be reported fairly. Here is what sparked my interest, urlLink CNN.com - Ohioevolution lesson plan irks science groups - Mar 10, 2004 "Critics say the lessons contain elements of a theory called intelligent design, which states a higher power must have been involved in the creation of life." So I thought it might be good to figure out what this "Intelligent Design" theory might be. I found this article that is a presentation from some of the proponents of "ID" and rebuttals from evolutionary scientists. urlLink Intelligent Design? A Special Report from Natural History Magazine The main arguments that these guys seem to be proposing are, 1. Irreducible Complexity, and 2. Specified Complexity "Irreducible Complexity" takes into account that at the molecular level "every cell contains many ultrasophisticated molecular machines." The problem that this makes for evolutionary theory is that if you take away any one part of these machines the whole thing ceases to work. Therefore it would have been impossible for these things to evolve but needed to be designed as a whole. "Specified Complexity" uses statistical theory and mathematics to determine whether something is occurring randomly or was designed by some intelligence. Similar methods are used in hard sciences like archaeology and forensics for determining whether there was human involvement and in looking at radio waves coming from space looking for some kind of intelligent communication. "ID" applies this same theory to human biology and "show that undirected natural processes like the Darwinian mechanism are incapable of generating the specified complexity that exists in biological organisms. It follows that chance and necessity are insufficient for the natural sciences and that the natural sciences need to leave room for design." The evolutionary scientists and the Natural History journal shoot both of these down rather precursorily by lobbing shots at the examples that the "ID" proponents used in their explanations. Looking at the urlLink Discovery Institute website I found that each of the proponents make a pretty good defense of their arguments. Ok, now back to Ohio, and the CNN article that got my attention in the first place. Well it turns out that the "ID" proponents already tried to get into the curriculum and failed. In this editorial in a Cincinatti newspaper, urlLink Don't let dogma censor teaching it comes to light what people in Ohio already know. This is not some religious coup over the science curriculum but the implementation of the state's science standards which requires students to know "how scientists continue to investigate and critically analyze aspects of evolutionary theory." They are not even using the ID theory material. But this is typical of an instance where science is overshadowed by political and philosophical debate. The decision by the Ohio school board is not opening the door to religion being taught in the science classroom, it is not even knocking on that door. The uproar is about whether evolution will even be allowed to be questioned any more! But what is purpose of science if not to question? My take on this whole thing is that the Discovery Institute is basically a few oddball scientists who are banding together to make their views heard because there is no other way the scientific community will listen to them. What makes them a bit more potent is that there are some political and philosophical groups that stand to gain from their ideas. I wonder what their motivations are? If they are truly motivated by science and truth then I would encourage them to do some hard scientific work. The examples that were given are really quite good, but they need to find 1000's of them. The problem of course is that requires funding, and then there wouldn't be any scientific journal that would publish their findings. Getting the scientific community to admit to an intelligent designer will be impossible. But perhaps true scientific work in this direction could poke a few more holes in their Darwinian infallibility field.

Japan is a famously insular society that is trying to adjust to the modern global society. Things like this new website from the Justice Ministry don't help. urlLink 'Fink-on-a-foreigner' Web site hit as xenophobic, faces review Visitors to the site, launched Feb. 16, can enter the name, address or workplace of any suspicious foreigners. The report is then automatically sent to regional immigration bureaus, which have jurisdiction over workplaces where foreigners are employed. Informants are asked to select a motive for reporting a foreigner from a list on the site. The reasons a foreigner can be reported include "causing a nuisance in the neighborhood" and "causing anxiety." This is a throwback to the neighborhood "goningumi" of the Edo period that were for mutual help but were also used for surveillance and religious persecution. The idea is that good Japanese citizens can keep an eye out for illegal aliens but what it will result in is harassment of anyone who has a neighbor who dislikes foreigners.

But they chose to stay because of God's great love. God has taken them home where there is no fear and no strain and much reward. CHRISTIAN CHILDREN FORCED TO BECOME NOVICE BUDDHIST MONKS BY BURMESE REGIME From: Christian Solidarity Worldwide For Immediate Release BURMA/INDIA (ANS) -- Children from Christian families in Burma between the ages of five and ten have been lured from their homes and placed in Buddhist monasteries. Once taken in, their heads have been shaved and they have been trained as novice monks, never to see their parents again. In a visit to Chin and Kachin refugees in New Delhi and Mizoram State, India, earlier this month, CSW heard accounts of cultural genocide and religious persecution and discrimination. The Burmese regime's forces offer incentives to impoverished villagers to convert from Christianity to Buddhism in Chin state, an area which is 90 percent Christian. Mountain top crosses have been destroyed and villagers forced to build Buddhist pagodas in their place, often having to contribute finances and labor. Christians are required to obtain permits for special events, and for any renovation or construction work. No permission for new church buildings has been given since 1994. Christians in the civil service are discriminated against, and no Christian can rise beyond the rank of Major in the regime's army. In addition to overt religious persecution, the Burmese junta, the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC) has adopted a deliberate policy of introducing crude alcohol to Chin State. The Chin culture forbids alcohol, but the SPDC has brought in large quantities of methylated spirits/industrial alcohol, which it sells cheaply on the streets to teenagers and young parents, especially on Sundays when people go to church. The medical effects include addiction, jaundice, toxic liver failure and damage to brain cells, in some cases leading ultimately to death. One Chin Christian told the CSW delegation, "It causes the breakdown of body, mind, spirit and society." Forced labor, a serious human rights violation, occurs "on a daily basis," often disrupting church and community activities. CSW received a copy of a recent letter from an SPDC commander to a village headman dated December 13 2003 demanding 40 porters from one village and 30 from another. In another area of Chin State, villagers were forced to porter from December 20 2003 until January 19 2004, and were therefore unable to celebrate Christmas and New Year in their communities. The visit was conducted jointly by CSW-UK and CSW-Australia. CSW is one of only a handful of international organizations to visit the Chin and Kachin. One Chin refugee told the delegation: "Many foreigners go to Burma's eastern border in Thailand, but until now no one has come to us. We used to pray for foreign NGOs to come to the western borders, and we used to weep when no one came." A Kachin refugee said: "It is true that we feel we are known by no one." The Chairman of the Chin National Front said: "Your coming here is a God-send." CSW is calling on the international community to respond to these reports of human rights violations in western Burma, which add to the catalogue of evidence of atrocities perpetrated throughout the country by the junta. "The forgotten Chin and Kachin peoples of Burma urgently need their voice to be heard," said Baroness Cox, a deputy speaker of the British House of Lords and CSW-UK's Honorary President, who led the delegation to India. "We appeal to the international community to increase pressure on the regime to stop its policies of ethnic cleansing, religious persecution, cultural genocide, forced labour and torture. We also urge other international Non-Governmental Organizations currently providing humanitarian assistance on the Thai-Burmese border to consider taking up the plight of the refugees and Internally Displaced People in the western regions of Burma too." For more information or a copy of the report, please contact Richard Chilvers, communications manager, CSW on +44 (0) 20 8329 0045 or email richard.chilvers@csw.org.uk or visit www.csw.org.uk. CSW is a human rights charity working on behalf of those persecuted for their Christian beliefs. We also promote religious liberty for all.

Wednesday, March 31, 2004 ITALIAN MISSIONARY WORKER KILLED IN UGANDA Murder comes less than two weeks after Americans were shot By: Stefan J. Bos Special Correspondent, ASSIST News Service KAMPALA, UGANDA (ANS) -- A 76-year-old Italian missionary has been killed in northern Uganda, less than two weeks after an American missionary couple was murdered in the troubled East African nation. Comboni missionary Father Luciano Fulvi was found dead in his room in the Layibi mission, outside Gulu, 360 kilometers (225 miles) north of the capital Kampala, the Missionary News Service Agency (Misna) reported Wednesday, March 31. Misna said the killing may have been carried out by bandits who apparently climbed over the walls surrounding the missionary compound, where people often seek refuge to escape attacks by rebels of the feared Lord's Resistance Army. On March 18 American missionary workers Warren and Donna Pett and student Isaac were also killed by money seeking gunmen who raided their Esther Evangelical School of Technology in the village of Aringa, about 496 kilometers (310 miles) northwest of Kampala, Africa Inland Mission said. Father Fulvi was originally from the Italian diocese of Pescia, in the province of Lucca. Misna said that a fellow priest at the mission noticed the Father Fulvi's door was open after he went to bed on Tuesday night. The colleague called out to him, but getting no response thought he was asleep and shut the door. POOL OF BLOOD It was only the next day after Father Fulvi did not show up for mass and that neither his bicycle nor car had been touched, that this colleagues went to his room and found him lying in a pool of blood, Misna said. Father Fulvi first arrived Uganda in 1956 and stayed until 1964 before continuing his work in England and Scotland. He returned to Uganda 1990 and stayed there to carry out pastoral services and teach young people, Misna said. The priest lived through difficult times, including the outbreak in his region of the deadly Ebola virus in 2000 which killed scores of people. "OPEN FOR EVERYONE" However "he was extremely open and had a smile for everyone. He never feared the difficulties presented by missionary life, particularly in the dramatic context of North Uganda, said MISNA editor-in-chief Father Giulio Albanese, who met him in the Layibi mission around three weeks ago, along with a journalist. With the death of Father Fulvi, 14 Comboni missionary Fathers and one Sister have been killed in the past twenty years in various circumstances in Uganda, Misna reported. Up to 4,000 priests and lay people are active for the Comboni Missionaries, an international Catholic group dedicated to spread the Gospel "and serving the poor, and working for the Reign of God." The Comboni Missionaries were founded in 1867, by missionary priest Daniel Comboni (1831-1881), who was born in the small town of Limone sul Garda (Brescia, Italy). He struggled against the slave trade in Central Africa, set up centers for the education and training of Africans, and became the first bishop of Khartoum (Sudan), the organization said

Bos Special Correspondent, ASSIST News Service BEIJING / NEW YORK (ANS) -- The United Nations said Wednesday, March 31, its special rapporteur on torture, Dutchman Theo van Boven, is heading to China, amid fresh reports that Christians are suffering abuse in jails and prison camps. I am going to see "The Passion of the Christ" tonight. Perhaps the only thing that bothers people more than the cross is the idea of the judgment of God on those who disobey Him. Here is an article on Hell from Richard J. Foster. urlLink TheOOZE - A Letter About Hell: Richard J. Foster In setting forth their case Universalists inevitably make the person and teaching of Jesus the center of their appeal. Jesus love and grace and compassion, and his assurance to us of Gods unconditional love and grace-filled acceptance. All true realities, to be sure. But, and here is the fatal flaw in all Universalist teaching, this Jesus to whom they appeal so ardently is the very one who teaches more emphatically about hell than anyone else in the entire Bible. This is a reality we simply cannot get around. Jesusthe compassionate Jesus, the forgiving and accepting Jesusnever flinches when it comes to the subject of eternity. Jesus' Authoritative Witness Throughout his preaching Jesus holds forth twoand only twopossibilities for human existence: everlasting happiness in the presence of God or everlasting torment in the absence of God. In the judgment of the nations recorded in Matthew where we hear those famous lines, I was hungry and you gave me food, I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink, I was a stranger and you welcomed me, I was naked and you gave me clothing, I was sick and you took care of me, I was in prison and you visited me we also read that the Son of Man welcomes the righteous into the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world and says to the wicked you that are accursed, depart from me into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels. And Jesus final summation to this story: And these (the wicked) will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life (Matt. 25:31-46). Now, we can legitimately argue about whether the eternal fire is literal or metaphorical, but we cannot argue over whether or not Jesus is intending to teach us that there are two final possibilities for human existence. He did not leave that matter open for debate. This fact is reinforced in the Gospel of John which, although it actually says very little about hell, does record Jesus words, the hour is coming when all who are in their graves will hear his voice and will come out-those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation (John 5:28-29). We simply cannot sneak around the fact that Jesus teaches that there are two outcomes to human destiny: the resurrection of life . . . the resurrection of condemnation. Jesus word about the reality of hell is unambiguous. In the story about the rich man and Lazarus, the rich man, after death, is described as In Hades, where he was being tormented and later in the story this place is described as this place of torment. Im sorry, I wish I could make the story sound better. Or have a happier ending. You remember, Im sure, how the rich man pleads with Father Abraham to have mercy on me and is told that this is not now possible and that between you and us a great chasm has been fixed (Luke 16:19-31). Equally unambiguous is Jesus word that not all will enter the Kingdom life which, of course, includes heaven as its natural outcome. When a fearful disciple asks the Master, Lord, will only a few be saved? Jesus replies, Strive to enter through the narrow door; for many, I tell you, will try to enter and will not be able (Luke 13:23-24, see also Matt. 7:13-14). As if this exchange were not enough Jesus next adds, go away from me, all you evildoers! There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and you yourselves thrown out (Luke 13: 27-28). I could go on, but perhaps these sample passages make sufficiently clear Jesus teaching on the matter. The epistles only reinforce Jesus outlook. Paul says that those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. . . . will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction, separated from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might. (2 Thess. 1:8-9). And Johns Apocalypse simply seconds and thirds the teaching: the devil . . . was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur, where the beast and the false prophet were, and they will be tormented day and night forever and ever, and then adds, as for the cowardly, the faithless, the polluted, the murderers, the fornicators, the sorcerers, the idolaters, and all liars, their place will be in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death (Rev. 20:10, 21:8).

This just in from Mark Penner, working on the visual sign language bible for the Japanese deaf. This really gives you an idea of the complexity of the work that he is doing. It is fascinating! Thanks for praying. My trip to Japan is almost over--I return to the U.S. today. Mostly I was working with Yoshi on the meaning check. For those who are new, a meaning check is when we show a draft of the translation to a signer unfamiliar with the Bible, and have them tell us what it says. It's amazing what you discover when you do this. Parts of the translation that seemed perfectly clear turn out to be saying something other than we thought, or arent understandable at all. Needless to say, this takes a lot of time. You want to ask questions that draw out what the listener understood without clueing them in to the right answer. What else takes time? Any number of things. Just now, we were going over Gen. 1:8 God called the expanse heaven. Yoshi and his translation helper spent a good 10 minutes discussing whether to end the sentence with a fingerpoint, with its called, with a single strong head nod, or a multiple firm head nod. And yes, though any one of the options were valid, it did make a difference in the flavor of the translation. Sign language operates in a completely different realm than spoken languages! Weve also spent hours on the transition between Gen 1:1 and 1:2, trying to render the text accurately in a way that leaves room for the many alternate interpretations (just as the original language text does and as printed language Bibles do). Of course, Gen 1 is the hardest part of the whole Bible for Sign Language translations, since it is so far outside the scope of anything anyone in the Deaf community has experienced, yet needs to be portrayed with a certain degree of visuality in order to communicate. Translation has gotten easier as weve gotten into the Noah and Abraham passages. Do keep praying. Mark and Mary Esther leave for Kansas the day after Mark gets back from Japan. Pray for a good time of reconnecting with their church there. Mark
